problem: Your math club has 20 members.  In how many ways can it select a president, a vice-president, and a treasurer if no member can hold more than one office?
solution: There are $20$ potential members that could be president. Once the president is chosen, there are $19$ that could be vice-president. Finally, once those two offices are filled, there are $18$ that could be treasurer. Thus, there are $20 \cdot 19 \cdot 18 = \boxed{6840}$ ways in which the math club can select the officers.
